subject: Re: And now for something completely different.
msgSnippet: ... That s one of the things that I found really frustrating while I working on the book. I kept trying to figure out the stress certain words in the
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan wrote:
> First of all, the only distinction that Shavian makes that Quikscript
> does not is between NURSE and LettER words, which are already fully
> separated because the NURSE vowel always bears the stress and the LettER
> vowel never does.

That's one of the things that I found really frustrating while I working on the book. I kept trying to figure out the stress certain words in the appropriate context, going around and around in my head, saying it out loud on its own and in context trying to get it "just right". Sometimes it could have been either or and I'd have to try and figure out how Poe wanted it to be pronounced until I eventually gave up and just metaphorically flipped a coin. Not having to do so probably would have saved me several months, or at the very least several weeks.

> Both alphabets make distinctions irrelevant to
> 99.6% of anglophones, which can be borne, but fail to make essential
> distinctions such as that between the vowels of "fork" and "pork",

Uh... what IS the distinction between "fork" and "pork"? Other than their initial letters, I pronounce both of those the same. So does the Gage Canadian Dictionary and the Oxford Australian English Dictionary. Interestingly, dictionary.com lists "Fork" as using Awe, but "pork" can use either Awe or Oak.

> or the sounds of "poor" and "pure", which is much worse.

Sorry, but I'd agree with you if you were right. :-) In Shavian, "poor" uses Ooze, while "pure" uses Yew. In Quikscript, "Poor" uses Ooze, while "pure" uses a ligature of Ye and Ooze.

> (And if you say, "We can live without those", I point out that
> about 62% of all anglophones manage fine without distinguishing all
> three sounds written Ah, Awe, On.)

Like me. Where I grew up, we don't distinguish ANY of them. Normally I'd just write them all as "On", but I came up with some guidelines to use so that I could distinguish them in the book, hopefully successfully. I pretty much camped right by my dictionary for the longest time while I was working on it for months before I (hopefully) worked out the pattern.
